titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Mary Barnard Papers
titlestmt.author: by Andrea Benefiel

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday April 25, 2019 at 03:07

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The papers document the life and literary career of Mary Barnard and consist of writings, correspondence, travel papers, diaries, photographs, and audiovisual materials, dating from the 1890s to 2001. Writings include drafts of published and unpublished works, research materials, and notebooks. Correspondence pertains mostly to Barnard's writing career and personal relationships, but also includes family correspondence. Correspondents include Ezra and Dorothy Pound and William Carlos Williams. Travel papers include diaries written by Barnard, passports, brochures, maps and printed ephemera. The collection also includes a small amount of daily calendars, photograph albums, artwork, and audio and video cassettes.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 18 (artwork) Boxes 19-20 (audio and video tapes): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Elizabeth Bell on the Eugene G. O'Neill Memorial Fund, 2005.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Mary Barnard Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Mary Barnard Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and in some instances minimal organization at or around the time of acquisition. Further description was carried out in 2011.

As a rule, descriptive information found in the Collection Contents section is drawn in large part from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.
Former call numbers: Uncat MSS 430, Uncat MSS 740

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Writings, 1932-1999. II. Correspondence, 1909-2001. III. Travel Papers, 1949-1994. IV. Calendars and Address Books, 1959-2001. V. Photographs, 1890s-1990s. VI. Other Papers, 1933-2001.

bioghist.head: Mary Barnard, 1909-2001
bioghist.p: American poet, biographer, and translator Mary Ethel Barnard was born in Vancouver, Washington on December 6, 1909. She was the daughter of Bertha Hoard and Samuel Melvin Barnard, who worked in the timber industry. After graduating from Reed College in 1932, Barnard established a relationship by mail with Ezra Pound, who became her literary mentor. Her poetry, prose, and translations of Greek poetry were published in literary magazines and as monographs. She was awarded numerous honors throughout her career, including the Levinson Award (1936), the Elliston Award (1979), and the Western States Book Award for Poetry (1986). Barnard died in 2001.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers document the life and literary career of Mary Barnard and consist of writings, correspondence, travel papers, diaries, photographs, artwork, and audiovisual materials, dating from the 1890s to 2001.Writings include drafts of published and unpublished works, research materials, and notebooks. Correspondence pertains mostly to Barnard's writing career and personal relationships, but also includes family correspondence. Correspondents include Ezra and Dorothy Pound and William Carlos Williams. Travel papers include diaries written by Barnard, passports, brochures, maps and printed ephemera. The collection also includes a small amount of daily calendars, photograph albums, artwork, and audio and video cassettes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series I contains drafts of poetry, prose, and translations of Greek poetry (all chiefly typescript), with a small amount of printed material and correspondence related to the writings. The series also includes research files consisting chiefly of notes and clippings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Titled Works, Untitled Works, and Research Files.

did.unittitle: Indexing proof and uncorrected page proof
Red notebook used in organizing book
"The Case of the Bottled Twins," typescript, corrected
Second draft of John's introduction, typescript
The Horae of Mary Ethel Barnard , typescripts
Books I and III, carbon copy
Books I and III, fair copy
Outline, introduction and draft of two chapters, typescript
"Time and Symbolism," typescript, xerox copies, and clippings related to topic
"Time and Tradition," typescript and research materials
Illustrations and correspondence by Anita Bigelow
Working versions of poems and translations, typescript and manuscript
Notes on "Drinks and Drugs," "Star Craft," and "Eclipses"
Notes on "Shamanism," "Soul Journeys," "Trees," "Water of Life," and "Center/Axis"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II contains the family and general correspondence of Mary Barnard, spanning 1909 to 2001. It contains primarily incoming correspondence, with a small amount of outgoing correspondence, both copies and originals. Principal correspondents include Marianne Moore, Winifred Overhoser, Dorothy Pound, Ezra Pound, and William Carlos Williams. In addition to letters, postcards, and other correspondence to and from Mary Barnard are a small amount of clippings and printed material, scattered writings by Barnard and others, genealogical research materials, and personal papers.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: Family Correspondence and General Correspondence.

arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III consists of material related to Mary Barnard's travels, including correspondence, printed material, notes, travel diaries, and passports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV consists of calendars, daily diaries, and an address book.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series V consists of photographs (including negatives) depicting Mary Barnard's family and travels.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Not arranged in any particular order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series VI consists of clippings and books, artwork by Mary Barnard, and audio and video cassettes.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three subseries: Printed Material, Artwork, and Audiovisual Material.
